title: ‘Anti-Nationals’ & 'Jihadi Terrorists' Were Involved In 1,450 Crimes In 2017, Finds NCRB
text:
After a delay of two years, the National Crime Records Bureau finally published its annual report on crime statistic in the country for 2017.

What sets this report aside is a new category, which in the previous years, had never been part of the report: “Crime Committed by Anti-National Elements”.

The chapter lists three kinds of “anti-national elements”: North East insurgents, Naxalites or Left Wing Extremists, and “Terrorists (including Jihadi Terrorists)”.

However, the terms “anti-national elements” and “jihadi terrorists” find no definition in the report.

The statistics show that “anti-national elements” committed 1450 crimes under various sections of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and Special Local Laws (SLL). The three aforementioned categories accounted for 421, 652, and 377 crimes committed by “anti-national elements” respectively.

According to the NCRB data, the maximum offences were committed by Left Wing Extremists (LWEs) (652), followed by North East insurgents (421) and Terrorists or Jihadi and other elements (371).

LWE operatives were found to be responsible for 82 killings according to the report, while terrorists were responsible for 36 deaths. Meanwhile, northeast insurgents killed 10 people.

LWE insurgents caused 72 deaths in Chhattisgarh, while 34 of the 36 deaths and 18 attempt to murder cases by terrorists were in Jammu and Kashmir alone.

The report also gives details of attacks by “anti-national elements” in 2017. As many as 269 civilians and police/state/army personnel were killed in these attacks in 2017.

Screengrab/The new chapter listed in the index of the report.

The NCRB report included 88 new categories including sexual harassment of women at the workplace/public transport, offences relating to elections, obscene acts at public places, circulation of fake news, chit funds, cases under the Prevention of Corruption Act and Mental Health Act, noise pollution and defacement of public property – also from adding “anti-national elements” and “jihadi terrorists”.

Since the BJP government came to power in 2014 and for the second tern in 2019, the term "anti-national" has been frequently used by prime minister Narendra Modi, Home Minister Amit Shah and other ministers of the ruling regime. It has been increasingly used in the country ever since the arrests of student leaders of Jawaharlal Nehru University early in 2016. In the current (rather loose) context, it may define anyone who disagrees with the popular "nationalist" narrative and is insufficiently patriotic per the BJP and its supporters.
